code:
S = input()

if S == "Sunny":
    print("Cloudy")
elif S == "Cloudy":
    print("Rainy")
else:
    print("Sunny")


This Python program works by taking the input string S, and then checks if it's "Sunny". If it is, it prints "Cloudy". If it's not "Sunny", it then checks if S is "Cloudy", and if it is, it prints "Rainy". If S is neither "Sunny" nor "Cloudy", it must be "Rainy", so it prints "Sunny".

This program is a simple switch-case statement, which is a common way to handle this kind of problem in many programming languages.

This program works by mapping each day of the cycle to the next day in the cycle, and then printing the mapped day based on the input.

This program assumes that the input will always be one of the three possible strings, "Sunny", "Cloudy", or "Rainy", as specified in the problem statement. If the input is something else, the program will not work correctly.

S

Sunny

-----Sample Output-----
Cloudy
